in pencil in top margin:  Rodgers, John C.
File:Drawing of upper half of body of a man at a typewriter  R.I

   I can't send in anything NEW -- my typewriter is on the blink -- and altho my son promised me a new one for Christmas, the new one is still in the offing.  Lack of money is the reason.
   I have a new, old one, that needs re-typing, "Marse John's Boy" -- that should be all right for the FOOLKILLER.

File:Drawing of barefoot man in overalls, walking

   And an oldie that "See Here, Marion Hargrove" said was "over the heads" of the average GI, which is a big tub of you-know what.  The "average GI" was just as smart as the "average professor" and that is a lot of who-struck-john, anyway you look at it.

File:Drawing of head and shoulders of a GI with caption "Duh? What'd ja say?

   Had a letter from Harry M.Caudill once -- about his Night Comes to the Cumberlands.  Have no hope for the Appalachians, souls or not.  Coal Companies have no feeling -- no heart -- no nothing, but a desire to get the coal.  Comstock, editor of the Hillbilly, or ex-editor, is a case in point -- he sees nothing wrong with Strip Mining -- a blind spot, but then he is a Republican, and must have a lot of blind spots.
   Hang in thar, and keep a-digging.  We-uns air a-hanging' on.  Thanks for the nibblings -- wasn't for you I wouldn't have nair a one.  Jack II
Completed

in pencil in top margin:  Rogers, John C.
Feb. 19, 1977
Jack oboy oboy:

     Had a note from Muhrer, said he "loved that Artist piece" or mine, and had found underlined:  two short stories of mine in the files!   Wrote to him and said I enjoyed doing the Artist' piece and hoped they liked underlined: one of the stories at last.  Gave him names of bookstores in area and Washington that underlined:  might be interested in handling FOOLKILLER, I sent a copy of the FOOLKILLER to Comstock, editor of the underlined:  W.Va. Hillbilly shock him out of his W.Va. wits, or maybe I am wrong?!  Comstock had a piece about a strikepoke in the last issue and I wrote him about underlined:   that and the fact a newspaper editor refused to print a word "funkeybutt" I had in an article - editor said the word had a "bad meaning" where he came from (the Deep South) - this was a Hearst paper - you'd think ANYTHING went in THAT!?  A Negro was here today, friend of my son's, and he read my piece in the FOOLKILLER -- said he didn't know until he read it that artists had such underlined:  a bad time -- he thought any time they wanted "freedom" they got it and no questions asked!  He hoped to see more of my stuff and also the FOOLKILLER.  Leo (the Negro) has a lot to learn about the U.S.A. - he works for a guvmint agency too -- moving furniture about.  A nice fellow, but I wonder where he has been ?!  We'll have to educate  him, slowly.  Salud,

Jack II
115 E Maple St. Va.  22301
Completed

[[pencil in top margin:  Rogers, John C. [1971]  ]]
Jack oboy oboy:

     Just made a trek down town - not much money and most places closed up - went into "Buddy's place" for a couple of brews, all the money I had.  Asked if Mr. Via had been in - he being in once while I was there - but it seems Mr. Via (George it seems) has a hangover and was absent.  One colored guy was present - they called him Shorty and Mr. Levi - he spoke to me, very civil and as tho he knew he had a PLACE in a white bar - some Irish piece was on TV - "Young Cassidy" -- full of Revolution and homey views, quite authentic sets I thought, tho' I knew nothing of the story.  So out on the street again and to home.
    Muhrer sent a brief note - said they had "discovered" two short stories of mine and would consider them -- he promised to write anon, which he may do, or may not.  did you like the reprint of my ART(ists) CAN BE FUN(ny)?  Thought they might have given the old NEWS a by-line, but what's done is done and I am not one to cry over spilt by-lines - Right?

Yrs in the brew (3.2).   Jack II.
Sent a copy of FOOLKILLER to Sterling A. Brown - he appreciated it.
in left margin:  George Via is a plumber-neighbor of ours - with a passel of kids and a mousey wife.
Completed

drawing:  3 men seated at a bar, bartender facing them
Buddy's Place. King Street.
Completed

March 30, 1977
Jack - oboy - oboy -

    We saw in underlined:  American Heritage - wasn't it? - an article about "SAM PATCH." the High Jumper - by some "folklore expert" at Bloomingdale, Indiana - no mention of the book by J. Conroy?  They should at least have given you a footnote!?!
   Yes, soon to be time for Poke Sallit - our favorite patch here is overgrown with Pizen ivy - the Italian pushcart vendors in Washington usually have poke sallit in Spring.  Have you tried young MILKWEED - called Wild Spinach in Canada.  I tried it once - rather bitter I thought.   John Rogers

in left margin  You wanta [sic] make underlined:  millions?  A musical re Sam Patch!  Yes.
Completed

File:Drawing of man with slumped shoulders; initialed R
It's purely hot here today - I went downtown early and almost passed out in a dugstore, called a cab, waited half-hour and then came home on a bus!  such is urban life in the Old Dominion, so-called.
Completed

pencil in top margin:  Rogers, John C.
July 5, 1977
Dear Jack-oboy oboy:

     Liked your story, The Morphadite, in underlined:  december.  Johnson returned my drawings and photo - he's a good guy, not like some of these editors who don't ever return stuff.
     Can't figure the magazine though - lots of poetry and photos.  He must have a following, although what kind or how many I have no idea.  At 4.00 each I can't get any copies.  He publishes for the money crowd I guess - well, I liked the photos and the way magazine is printed.
     What did you think of Murrell Edmunds; "Reservoir" - I would say that is not his cup of tea - although everybody seems to be getting into it - except Conroy and Rogers - got enough to do with keeping the STRAIGHT copy STRAIGHT.
      Muhrer and Lovejoy spent two days with me, putting the sleeping bags in our basement.  Took me for a crab feast down Maryland-way and to an outside bar in D.C. - they went to Old Heidelberg one night and liked it (my old hangout) - said it had a good stew and dark German beer.  Guess they are back in Missouri by now.  Bit of Bluegrass freaks, aren't they?  

Salud,
Jack 
114 E Maple Street
Alexandria Va  22301
Completed

pencil, top margin  Rogers, John C.
July 14, 1977
Jack oboy oboy!

    How do you figure the enclosed?  Trying to get me to turn my back on all that I hold most worthwile [sic] in this topsy-turvey [sic]  world?  I note on their list of sponsors some guys that I always thought were pretty good:  Loren Eiseley, Charles Addams, Eric Hofer (with reservations), Peter Hurd -- Joseph Coors I knew was no good from days as a GI in Denver insert in left margin with line pointing here:  Joseph Coors still brews good beer.  Richard Boone I knew nothing for or agin him until this list.  Oh, well, you can't win 'em all.  I thought of writing the Association and then thought I wouldn't - let them stew in their own juice, it must be nice for the FBI to feel put upon, they for so long had the field to themselves and put it ALL on US!
   Hear from Dellinger (FOOLKILLER) that the wandering minstrels have returned to home port - much sadenned [sic] and disillusioned from their first Conference - they asked me to go along, but I declined gracefully I hope.  They particularly objected to "the Lesbian poetry" - which Dellinger found ODD on their part.  I have three photos I took as they were leaving - will send to them soon as the Photo Shop delivers to me - came out Okeh - took the photos with the same little camera I snapped you with in Chicago, and took pix in St. Lous of the Milles (?) fountain - a very good little camera considering the way I've abused it.  Just thought I'd write and send you the inflammatory stuff.

Bottoms up!  Jack II
in left margin  Sally Brown just had an operation, and is home recovering.  Dee Brown liked FOOLKILLER - I sent him a copy.  Their address:  seven Overlook Drive  LITTLE ROCK, AR,   72207
Completed

pencil in top margin:  Rogers, John C.
July 20, 1977
Jack oboy oboy:

   Didjer ever see these two Bluegrass Freaks afore?  Came by and staid two nights, then went on to a meeting of the minds in the Nawth, where they ran afoul of some Lesbian poetry and then came tew home, which they should never have left, according to all the rumors and such like down heah.
   I guess they are both sadder and wiser peoples.  
   Have you heard nought of them?  Fixing up their place in K.C. MO. in "French provincial" according to Wild Harry Dellinger -  gold walls with white trim!!  They'll be sending out The Foolkiller with French didoes around the border next, ah me, such is life in Kansas City, MO!
   I guess the two rambling romeos are safe at home port - I had a bout in D.C. and Maryland with 'em - oh, if I was only younger.

Salud,
Jack
Completed

pencil in top margin  Rogers, John (Jack) 
115 E Maple St.
Alex. VA.  22301
10 Aug. 1977
Jack oboy oboy:

    Hope things are better by you and the Missus is on her feet again and no more pixilated mind.
    Enclose a copy of letter from Dee Brown, who is one with troubles, altho I can't figure his sun-trouble from afore WWII - I was on the same river, same time he was, and I never cotched [sic] it - I guess the Potomac just picks on certain people, or somethin'.
    I didn't know about old Howard Fast, thought he was a gone one I did - shows to go you WE all got our exception to the rules, or something!
     Hot'ern the hinges of hell around here - I even go out in the heat, seeing as how I can take it, but I guess it will strike me down afore I know what hit me, or don't you think that will happen to an old Shike Poke like I'm?   Well, we shall see, as the farmer said when he kissed the cow, or was it a mule?  I disremember a lot, I do,  Fact is, I'm surprised that I get so much done, I am for a fact.
   Drank a fifth of 100 proof Old Grandad by myself the other eve - never fazed me - did it gradual as it were.  Oh, I'm a card I am, the Doc thinks I'm his Special Project, as it were.

86s  Jack II
pencil in bottom margin  Rogers
Completed

pencil in top margin  Rogers, John C.
29 Aug 1977
Jack oboy oboy:

      A nice bosomy lady, yclept Barbara Hogan says she will write to you, enclose a story for your edification and ask you where to send such - I told her to go ahead, you were a nice man and she'd no doubt hear from you.  I've been vegetating and in no arting or writing mood, besides the Weather Report says it is extremely hazardous for people like I'm to be out, and I just came back from the Library but didn't notice any difference in the air.  Don't have any beer to cut the pollution with, either.
     Haven't heard from KC, MO. for past month or two - Dellinger was worried because his second child was late in coming - doc said it would probably be the 25th, but 25 is past and no word.  Got to worry about the FOOLKILLER and then worry about the kid!!
     Hope you are OK, and making it OK too - all we can do in this best of all possible worlds  - who said that?  Voltaire?  Sent some pix to Minature Show in D.C. - probably get 'em all Rejected.

Peace,
Jack
Completed

pencil in top margin to Conroy
Nov. 5, 1977
Dear Jack, oboy, oboy:

      First:  congrats on receiving the grant from the Nat'l Endow. for the Arts - yes, I am surprised the FBI and the Un-American hounds didn't crucify you for being a dangerous CommuNEEist - they sure got a lot of others who probably didn't deserve it nuther, but they made 'em suffer as they made me - it ain't no fun and now maybe some of the good people have seen the error of their ways and wish to do some good.   I haven't seen the list of the gratees [sic] if I do I will get a copy to  you.  Any lead where to look?
     Dellinger wrote about the delay and the grand new building they were moving into - said they had money trouble also, but it was nothing they couldn't solve, and hoped to do better in the future.   They have a good thing and I hope they do have smoother sailing.
    Thanks for doing the "little introductory sketch" - I am sure it is going to be okeh - having an introduction by Conroy is much, too much!   I have just written for the record of underlined:  folk sounds Judy put out some time ago - didn't have a record player then -- my son just got one.  so, we'll be hearing Judy.
     How come VODKA only 80 Proof?  It might be a 100 year distillery, but it sure doesn't prove it by making 80 Proof VODKA - hope their bourbon is better.  They make Applejack in Va. at 100 proof!  120 proof at moonshiner's.  Hang in there.    Jack  in pencil:  Rogers
Completed

pencil in top margin  Rogers, John C.
14 Jan  1978
Jack oboy oboy:

      They swing around in a small circle and trip themselves up - like my lawyer said Clarence C. Tormoen, Personnel Security Officer, for the Internal Revenue Service or Treasury - was all hot about a gal who was in the Young Communist league, when Tormoen was in collitch in Minnesota or wherever he went - my lawyer was from those parts and knew Tormoen - Tormoen is dead now - too much security checking was bad for his heart.
   Well sending on this appeal - couldn't happen to better people - only I don't think things are as bad as the Right pictures it - if it only WERE.  Oh, well we can dream can't we, or is that forbidden to victims of the FBI and other law repressive organizations.
    Been a long time without FOOLKILLER  - you think they are bogged down?
    Got some Irish Mist.  First time I had it - reason I got it, sold underlined:  two prints so felt I could afford it - real nice stuff - may get overcome.  How come these furriners mix up such nice tasting stuff?  Remember other stuff I had - underlined: and I'm not supposed to drink much - altho I incline to disremember my operation - it's been so long ago - 1970!
    Hanging in there, Jack II.
Completed

19TH Feb. 1978
Jack oboy oboy:

    Received advance copy of the FOOLKILLER  - wasn't much of your article (?) in it, but thanks for the kind words - and the pitchers reproduced quite well, I think.  They made a boo-boo which I shall overlook - had me born in the Appalachians, which I merely visited - one of those many artists who seldom strayed from his place of birth - Alexandria - if the army hadn't come along I wouldn't have seen you in Chicago, or Colorado, or Utah, or Oklahoma.  Thanks a lot for the boost - my son is always after me to "DO SOMETHING NEW" - frankly am in a rut, don't do nothing much.  Maybe I will some day, but it takes more energy than I have.  Guess I am on the skids.  Didn't know KC was having a crime wave  until I read Muhrer's piece - gosh, he better watch his writing or someone will fit him for a cement overcoat.
    How are you?  How is your wife?  I'm hanging on barely - doc now trying to get my heart beating normal.  EKG looked like this:  drawing of flat line with two peaks in the middle  doc gave me some new pills and have to go back in TWO weeks - used to be every underlined:  TWO MONTHS.  Poke sallat will fix me up.

Hanging in there, Jack II.
drawing of three green leaves poking out of the ground

in pencil in top margin Rogers, John C.  [1978]
[[IMAGE:  4 sketches with captions]
X-RAY  back view of bald man wearing shirt and pants facing a rectangular screen
EKG two-paneled screen
PHARMACY  ABOUT $200 WORTH OF FREE MEDICINE  upper body of bald man receiving a box from a window
WHAT I DON'T UNDERSTAND IS THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN GIVING A PATIENT FREE MEDICINE AND THE DRUG STORE CHARGING A HIGH PRICE FOR THE SAME MEDICINE?  back view of a bald man's head
IT IS ASTHOUGH [sic] WE HAD SOCIALISM WORKING FOR A CERTAIN CLASS AND A DOG-EAT-DOG SYSTEM WORKING FOR A CERTAIN CLASS.  DO YOU AGREE?  THIS COULD BE FOLLOWED UP AND SOME DIFFERENCES MADE.  I WOULD NOT LIKE THE DIFFERENCES MADE TO MY DISFAVOR.

   RECENTLY I HAD TO GO TO NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH, BETHESDA, MARYLAND - WE WILL SPARE YOU THE DETAILS OF MY BUS TRIP, THREE CHANGES ENROUTE AND THREE CHANGES RETURN - A STOP AT THE OLD HEIDELBERG ON WAY BACK - I LIKE MY LOCAL DOCTOR - BUT I THINK HE IS TIRED OF ME - HE WANTS ME OFF - I OWE HIM $300 in back fees - fees he charged me ILLEGALLY - fees he charged beyond the fees allowed by the BLUESHIEILD [sic] - he knows this and still he charges, them, I refused to pay.

Yours, in travail,
Jack
Completed

clipping from magazine
handwritten in ink  July 1

File:Sketch of man in short sleeved shirt and pants, wearing a hat and carrying a sack

115 E. Maple Street., Alexandria, Virginia
The question is:  will there be death after 1985?  You have disposed of the question about life.  I think most citizens will accept the fact, generally speaking, life could come to a halt after 1985.  So what?  We are living too fast, moving too fast.  Say we had to go to a horse-and-buggy pace, take us hours to go a hundred miles?  Too slow, say the speedsters.  Not slow enough, says Old-Rocking-Chair-Got-Me.

    As a boy, spending summers on my grandfather's farm in the Blue Ridge, nothing impressed me as much as the uselessness of speed as a three-mile trip to the mill with Grandpa's sorrel mare Dixie, to have some of Grandpa's eatin' corn turned into meal.  The trip was timeless and pleasant.  There were birds and squirrels to watch and, if lucky, a skunk or a grey fox.  Back home I was expected to recall as well as I could, gossip from the mill, the store and blacksmith shop.  I was the newspaper we didn't receive.  Traveling at sixty miles an hour, costs us the above.

John C. Rogers
handwritten in ink  W.Va. Hillbilly
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Rogers, John C.
Jack oboy oboy:

    Wrote to Judy, promptly at your suggestion.  Didn't hear nothin' - poor fellow, I'm afraid something serious has happened - he was always a happy-go-lucky cheerful sort of fellow - can't imagine him with something like CANCER to plague him.  Called the last phone number I had - no answer.  205-438-4805 -- got him one time at that number.  Judy and Murrell Edmunds - Edmunds wrote me that he seldom goes out - sits in his room and contemplates I suppose, like an ancient ?stoic?.  I couldn't figure out his last book, underlined:  Reservoir - not the ending no way - no way.  Guess old Murrell was trying to tell us SOMETHING, but it somehow failed.  Murrell has a lot on the ball - I'm sorry for him the book did not come across stronger.  You can see the same thing in Alexandria - only the black-white couples go about it quite openly - with what results I am afraid to guess.
   How's the wife.  Better I  hope.
   How am I?  Just hanging in there.
   Yep, the ole FOOLKILLER got a big staff, but not much git up and go.  A good magazine tho', once hit gits out.

Yrs, Jack II
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Rogers, John C.
Sep. 5, 1978
Jack, oboy oboy:

    How you doin'?  Had a note from Hal L. Dellinger, one of the FOOLKILLER tribe - he surmises the FKiller will emerge somewhat in the near future, I agree with you, I can't figure out what takes the FOOLKILLER to appear with any regularity - considering the staff they have got.  Maybe us don't know what distractions K.C. Mo. has to offer?
    Did you ever hear from Judy?  I didn't and I had a report from Nelson Rosenberg, an artist friend Judy knew in Wash. D.C. - Nelson said he tried a phone call and was not rewarded with an answer - he assumed Judy was out.  Can you elaborate on the above?
    An, gawd, how life gets more troublesome as one gets older.  My son puts up with my eccentricities.  I hope.  My doctor shows no such tolerance.

More in the hope then [sic] in the reality.  V.O. in reserve.
Yrs in travail, Jack II
Completed

in pencil in top margin  Rogers, John C.
Sep. 25, 1978
Jack oboy oboy:

    What makes you think the Alexandria Library carries Soviet Life?  It carries a magazine from the Peoples Republic of China, but nothing so subversive as a Soviet publication.  Did you get my card with the "421" address?  I thought so, a renowned writer like you.  I'll try and get an address for you, if I have to call the Soviet Embassy, after all I was once suspected of being a known subversive and I still have a warm spot in my heart for things Soviet.  I suspect the mag is published in New York.  But old Rogers will deliver the address.
   Guess Old Judy has kicked the bucket - he don't answer you and he don't answer me.  A good guy gone.
   The old haunts at North Garden were not much - I went into the Brass Rail in downtown Charlottesville, and had me five Bud's - thought that was the least I could do to boost the economy, which was booming with a new Mall, etc.  Met a guy I hadn't seen for some 20 years - a miller from North Garden.  He was prosperous and worried about the future - he thought we were being sold out to the Communists!  Letting all those Viet Nam into the USA!

Jack II.
written in left margin  Soviet Life  Embassy of the Soviet Union in the USA   Oleg P. Benyukh, Editor   1706 18th Street N.W.  Washington, D.C.  20009
Completed

The Sage of Moberly

Nov. 15, 1978.
Jack oboy oboy:  Well, Judy is still alive - feeding him hormones according to Nelson Rosenberg - Nelson says Judy is still not so hot, according to Judy, but he is taking an interest in things, so to speak.  Thought I would pass the info on.
I never got a reply to letter I sent, but that is water-over-the-dam, or something!?  Judy is getting $150 a month from his WWII service and according to Nelson he may be in line to get more, if Judy can find out how to go about it.  Our neighbor, who was in WWI and wounded, said to me just the other day that he had decided the veterans were getting screwed - he's 84, on the 13th - a nice old Italian guy who doesn't bother anyone - so he says.

   The other day, the 14th, I went to doctor for my check-up -- said I was doing well as could be expected, and a week hence the doc was changing my pills, since he assumed I only had a few - I had 800 in eight bottles - his secretary told me those 800 pills were worth between 30 and 40 dollars -- I asked her if maybe I could make a trade, she said no but may be  the doc would keep me on the old medicine since I had so much of it.  The doc didn't say that, so assume I am stuck with 800 pills, a gift from the Clinic.  
   Have to lug 'em way back to Clinic!  Trouble, trouble.  Yrs, Jack II
Completed

pencil in top margin Rogers, John C.
Jan.  20, 1979
Jack oboy, oboy:  

     Dee Brown reports Vance Randolph still alive in a nursing home at Fayetteville, drinking his quart of Bourbon a day, they say, and his wife too.  Two quarts!!  in left margin with arrow pointing to this paragraph:  And my doctor frowns at one cocktail!
     Dee says he is getting old, can't remember nothing and it takes him longer to write a page now than it did to write ten pages a few years ago.  If he goes out to get something he can't remember what it was.  Sounds a bit like me, only not that bad.  Ice frozen on walks today - fell once with a fifth of Canadian Club, didn't break nothing though and picked myself up.  Serve me right for going out this kind of weather!!  But if I wait for weather to change I'd never get out.
   A&P closing tonight.  Nice store, I did all our shopping there.  Now have to go to Grand Union, but they have Molson's Ale, or did.  Things are getting rougher and rougher for us golden oldies, and that's a fact.
    Guess old Rayford is just about holding his own.  Wish I was in Mobile and could drop by and cheer him up - iffen I could.  Will try and get the book you mentioned at liberry, but doubt if they have it.
   Spring is far behind.

Jack II.
Completed

File:Drawing of man dressed in jacket, hat and plaid pants leaning on shovel with one hand, other hand raised to face
Jack I:
Blizzard of Feb. 20, 1979 - Rogers is about to struggle fourth or fifth in order to repair damage or restore dignity to walks that were done sparingly or not at all by black teen-agers who collected and then beat it and didn't do a good job.  Jeff would have done it, but he has went to Jamaica with money received from sale of his stero [sic] equipment, leaving me to take care of cat, named "Primo" - which I didunt do a good job - let him out last night and he made good his escape - not back by 7:52 PM as I can testify.  If he's not back by tomorrow, guess he has gone for good - we've had him a good three years and I for one will miss him - most of [sic] got lost in a drift - the snow drifted in spots.

   Hope all is well on the Moberly front - you didn't get all this snow did you?

15 March 79
Dear Jack, oh boy:

   I am absorbing some french brandy, called underlined:  Marnier as well as I remember.  It is underlined:  imported stuff, but don't let that fool yah - it is pure apple-jack - I can taste the apples in it.  I am well under control as the controls should go.  Are you under controls, as controls should be?  I am about to espouse my cause to the right effort - come what May,  The cat (Premo) was up on the drawing table a moment ago - he uses it as a sleeping perch and can look out the windows at the birds he wants but can't get.  Unlucky cat!
Completed

It is now Sunday.  I have perused the newspaper and find nothing to stimulate me or move me to greater efforts.  It seems to me that WWIII is on the way, of course we won't go, having no gas to run our fatal attack combos, which is ironic as a neighbor pointed out today - we sell thousands of cars and now find we don't have gas to run them.   He use to work where I did and is trying to be a landlord - a rather decent chap, if he didn't have an extra house saddled upon his back, but puddles away, painting here, cutting there and taking it all quite cheerfully, he thinks.

   We have a new Irish pub downtown - MURPHY'S - I have not been in it yet, but my son has and reports are good = Irish Harp in large glasses, and other Irish goodies at reasonable prices.  Must go some day, may be make a sketch.  I haven't made a sketch for some time of anything, so should be rewarding.  All these new eating places - I don't see how they can survive?  Someone asked Murphy how long he expected to last and he said "a hundred years".  Well maybe he will, but I won't be here to find out, neither will Murphy!  Best wishes, Jack

What do you hear from Judy Rayford?

May 6,  1979
Jack oboy oboy:

    I writ [sic] to Judy and received no reply.  Does that mean the old boy has succumbed to cancer or what ever?  The letter was not returned so I assume Judy received same.
    Wish I could get to the Conference, but I guess I better stay to home and send them my good wishes.  Spring has sprung and us (my son and I) planted some rose bushes and sowed some seeds - I note some of the seeds are coming up - *gladiolae and morning glories - we await the others - sunflowers, etc. - as my son says - we must of done something right.  Hope the sunflowers come up - they are the MOST of plantings - plus, the birds like them.  written in left margin:  *The gladiolas were a gift from a mail order company.

May 22, 1979
Dear Jack oboy oboy:

    How goes it?  I just came back from my yearly visit to Nat. Institutes of Health, after a long, rambling ride by Airport Limousine, up the Potomac River until we crossed over into Maryland - cost me 4.75, but was worth the price.  Delivered me right to the door, no hassle.  The doc would probably have said OKeh to my going to Kansas City, but I didn't press my luck.  He said there was nothing new they could do heart-wise for me, gave me a clean bill and a fresh pack of medicines and soon I was on the way back to home.  Stopped off in Washington to get some old Scotch, unblended, the kind they don't sell in Alexandria -- good, good, good.  By the way, what of Old Judy Lee Rayford?  I wrote to him and letter was not returned.  Nelson Rosenberg wants to know also - Nelson used to call him - Nelson is from Durham, North or South Carolina - I guess Judy is just getting "sot" in his ways and refuses to do nothing for nobody.   Lemme know if Judy is still Judy or if there is a turn for the worse.  We had a mess of poke sallit greens 'tother day - picked from my back yard.  Right tasty - altho I noticed my son didn't eat much (as I did).  I guess he will have to grow to like it.  Like us.

Salud,   Jack

Dear Wendell - Don and I dearly love "Master Drummond on a Horse", and as with you, we need cheering.  Today is underlined:  so gloomy.   Our faithful little Radio is throwing out Mozart's Don Giovanni - wonder if  you are getting it.  It is now Sunday - clear, sun brightly shining.  I do not know what or whoom [sic] to blame if I can't get this letter to you, in Don's hands, so he can add details of all happenings to you - unless numerous 'phone calls come in and hold him for hours.  This took place yesterday - two of Dan's women friends even came over here to the house.  Don did remember to tell them he and others had to do the same, leave the hospital, and become out patients again, as there was a shortage of beds.  Don did not want these friends to visit the hospital and find he had left.  Herman Rivers is the man Don mentioned to you, who died on
Completed

his floor February 14th.  Don went to see him every day, even when he was in a coma and he did not meet one of the visiting relatives at the time, he went to Herman's room, he would report by 'phone to one or two members of his family.

   Yes, but they were to be frank and write what they didn't like about the story as well as what they did.  The author is interested in their criticisms.  They help him.
    So they were on their own (the papers look it), but I knew you'd like it that way.  There was only one correction, on Jimmy Gentile's paper.  That's so you'd know what he meant.  He said the word "magnificent," but he couldn't spell it.
    Don't worry about everybody thinking the ending sad.  The children understood why Slappy had to go away and leave Mike Flint.
    Thanks again for the book and the nice inscription, though what I've done to deserve it I don't know.

   As Johnny said last week when the patrol boys came in,"  I aint done nuttin, teacher.  Honest, I aint."  But if I can do sumpin', please let me know.   I'd like to, very much.
   Lots and lots of luck and royalties.

Sincerely,
Hilda Rosenberg

March 20, 1947
Dear Mr. Conroy,

   Thanks for the story.  You should have sent the other along, too.  It's absolutely worthless.
   You know, for a minute there after you had asked for it, I was all for deporting Mr. Thurber and Mr. Perelman, but when I took the story out of the shoe box and read it again, was all for deporting myself to farthest Siberia to live on eels and sea weed.  Ugh!
   The story definitely belongs in a shoe box - with the cover sealed down tight.   Anyone can see it's a masterpiece of the Shoe Box School.  (Founder - H. Rosenberg Ph.D., L.L.D. & D.D.S.)

February 4, 1948
Dear Mr. Conroy,

   If my sister can get away this month, she plans to go to New York and see some of the agents Mrs. Dickey kindly told her about over the telephone.   What Mrs. Dickey didn't know, however, was whether any of these agents would be interested in fantasy.  A great many publishing houses won't touch it with a ten-foot pole, and neither will some of the agents, I gather.
     Do  you know anything about the following, and whether they will be willing to read "fairy tales" ?

The agents are:

February 16, 1948
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    Thank you for the information.  You've been awfully kind to me, and to show my appreciation I should like to send you something on St. Patrick's Day to toast the "Ould Sod" with.
    Children like a great many things in a story, but what they would rank first, if they thought about it, would be sincerity.  No child is going to believe in an author's work if he doesn't. 
    Then comes action, which satisfies his unconscious desires.  No sooner do I finish reading a story then up shoot the hands, and Raymond becomes a monkey, Allen a king, Diane a rabbit, etc.  And a blackboard eraser is a present for the King, and the yardstick a sceptre [sic] of power and might.
Completed

-2-

  Human interest is a necessary ingredient, too, and humor, oh, lots of humor.  Lots of "talking", too.  Descriptions, yes, if one makes them short and colorful - full of "picture words", as my children would tell you.  and, of course, everything in the story must have a name since children live in a concrete world.
   The group I like best to write for are the 8-9 yr. olds.   They have a tremendous sense of fun, and live in the world of imagination.   The more fantastic a story is the better they like it.
    After that age children become more practical and read biography, history, stories of foreign lands, inventions, adventure.  Mystery, hobbies, etc.  About 13 girls begin to read romantic stories; boys much later.  After 13 children go in for specialized reading.
Completed

-3-
The little ones like rhythm, so we give them jingles: and repetitions - "Little Pig, Little Pig, let me come in.  No by the hair of my chinny chin chin," etc.

     Hope this is of help to you.  I'm sorry underlined:  Tellable Tales will not be published.  We could use a book like that in the schools.  Parents could too, if they'd realize the tremendous value of reading aloud to their children.
   R-ring!  There goes the bell!  Must out into the yard now and get the children off the apparatus and into line.   It's like pulling teeth.

Best wishes,
Hilda S. Rosenberg.
Completed

May 5, 1948
Dear Mr. Conroy,

    Thank you for your letter.  The poet story was thrun [sic] into the ash-heap, and another is taking its place - a thing called "The Great Hopscotch Mystery."   Mr. Snodgrass is a detective in this one,  has a very proper kit, and looks for clues in everything.  But Mrs. Snodgrass is very happy about the whole thing.
    "I'm glad," she said to herself, "he's decided to give up being a magician.  He was always wanting to saw somebody in half."
    And thank you for telling me about Miss Stewart of Reilly and Lee.

Dear Mr. Conroy,

   Elizabeth Stewart  very kindly said she liked underlined:  The Seven Lucky Sweaters ("it's humor was unusual and appealing") (sweet!) but the list has been curtailed and she couldn't take the story so one must wait patiently for Der Tag, and go on writing.  Couldn't stop now anyway.  Herbert Snodgrass would hound me.  I'm taking him to Nova Scotia with me, also Mrs. S. and the five children and will put them in another book.

Feb. 20, 1949
Dear Mr. Conroy,

   I was very sorry to hear Esta was ill, and hope she is well again.  That was nice news you sent about James Light, though.  A doctor's degree!   Hmm.  Must remember not to drop my haitches when I speak to him.
  Thank  you for letting me know about the Follett Award.  The blank came yesterday, and I've been drooling ever since.  The closing date of the contest isn't until Sept. 1, so there will be plenty of time to try my hand at a brand new story.  Have an idea.  Hope it works out.  It will be for
Completed

the  8 - 12 group, a most neglected group of children according to Miss Bauerle of the Austin Branch Library.  She told me more books are published for the smaller children and the teen-agers than for the middle group.

   Have you written any more folklore stories lately?  The children keep asking me when the author of "Slappy" and the "Sooner Hound" will bring out another book.
   We're coming to hear you lecture at the Jewish People's Institute in March.  Will see you then.  In the meantime, good luck, and thank you again.

Sincerely,
Hilda Rosenberg
